instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air No Display
threads.message:
We have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that customer said was flickering all of a sudden and then it just went black. He said he didn?t drop, didn?t spill anything on it. No faint display when flashing a light over it. No signs of corrosion - completely clean. Tested a known working board and the display assembly is working.

What is the next step to troubleshooting this?

Thanks!

EDIT: I forgot to mention that the MacBook turns on. Chimes, etc.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air No Display
threads.message:
Do you get 3V at pins 18/19 of J8300?
Check it when machine chimes; should appear at least 1-2s.
If not, check L8304.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air No Display
threads.message:
3.3 volts at pins 18/19 of J8300 for a few seconds when machine chimes, yes. Connector looks good, continuity on all pins. l2c sda/scl lines check out too.

<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> 0 volts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air No Display
threads.message:
I hope you checked with LCD connected.
<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> should rise to 3V at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air No Display
threads.message:
Unfortunately, yes I did check with LCD connected. I wish it was that easy lol

And yes, 3v split second then 0v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air No Display
threads.message:
If you detect pulse at <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL>, then check al data lines; voltage and diode mode to ground.
Also check the four C832x capacitors and R836x, as all pull-down resistors too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air No Display
threads.message:
Okay,

With LCD (pulse lasts a split second)
<RESISTOR>R8318</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R8317</RESISTOR> OL (or super high resistance) 0.13v to 0v pulse
<RESISTOR>R8380</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R8370</RESISTOR> OL 1v to 0v pulse
<RESISTOR>R8361</RESISTOR> - 0.5 diode - 3v to 0v pulse
<RESISTOR>R8362</RESISTOR> - 0.5 diode - 3v to 0v pulse
<RESISTOR>R8360</RESISTOR> - 0.55 - 3v -> 0 pulse

Without LCD (pulse lasts 2-3 seconds as compared to with LCD)
<RESISTOR>R8361</RESISTOR> - 0.7 - 3.3 -> 0v pulse
<RESISTOR>R8362</RESISTOR> - 0.7 - 3.3 -> 0v pulse
<RESISTOR>R8360</RESISTOR> - 0.7 - 0v

Caps all have 0.25 on diode pin 1 and OL pin 2
All traces from pin 2 of all 4 caps to connector checks out fine

Connector looks pristine condition. Could there be an issue with the SMC or traces to the SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air No Display
threads.message:
PCH is involved there.
Did you check diode mode with red probe at ground?
Do you get external video?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air No Display
threads.message:
Yes, red probe on ground.

I checked external display and it doesn't output anything here either. As soon as I plug in the charger, the monitor LED indicates a device is connected through HDMI however just a black screen. Chimes and everything still.

I also notice that for the internal display, when we get 3.3 volt pulses on the pin 18/19 the screen goes to a really dark black and then goes "neutral" black again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air No Display
threads.message:
Looks like iGPU issue, if no external video too.
Test external monitor disconnecting internal LCD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air No Display
threads.message:
Okay, yes I did that. I guess it's an iGPU issue..

Could it be anything else?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air No Display
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air No Display
threads.message:
I was putting this aside for a while. I'll give the USB drive with LED a try.

One question: can failed hall sensor cause no output to external display? The customer mentioned the screen was flickering before it went black forever.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air No Display
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air No Display
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is 3.45 volts. USB activity is confirmed. Hmm..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air No Display
threads.message: Do PRAM reset 2-3 times, just in case...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Air No Display
threads.message: Tried, but nothing. Closing up - unrepairable.
